bboxes.raw_text:
NEW YORK-Boycotts, sit-ins,
freedom marches, demonstra-
lions and picket lines are wea-
pons in the biggest public rela-
lions effort in the United States
today. 1t is the mass persuasion
campaign Of American Negroes to
achieve equal opportunity without
the violence that usually accom-
panies revolutions. The Public
Religions Quarterly, recognizing
the significance of this move
ment to the business community,
devotes a major portion Of its
current issue to the public re-
lations of the integration strug-
gle.


Whitney M. Young. Jr., execu-
tive director Of the National Ur-
ban League, a pioneer group in
the equality campaign for Ne
groes presents an interview In
the issue by Howard Penn Hud-


son, editor. Mr.. Young outlines


the background Of the organiza-


lions involved in the civil rights


battle and describes how petty

Public Relations Magazine
Traces Infegrution Issue

differences were submerged to
present common front.


Discussing the relation Of busi-
ness to integration, MIR. Young
warns businessmen against
maintaining stereotyped attitudes
toward Negroes, citing the his
torical fact that many Of today s
businessmen we're themselves
once victims Of stereotype pref
udice. Besides, he points out,
Negroes are a potential fertile
market for all kinds of con-
sumer goods.


Problems of unequal employ
ment are examined in "a Man
agement Perspective Toward Ne
gro Economic Pressures," con-
tributed by Hugh C. Hoffman Of
Opinion Research Corporation.
He describes the steps COM
panies and Negro groups have
taken to end these practices and
explains how companies can bring
about better understanding of Ne
gro workers and their problems.

Feb. l3 at Ebeneezer Baptist
Church. Rev. J. F. Pierce Of
ficiated,


Newford Jones, ST., vice chief
grand mentor, assumes grand
mentor position. He and the chief
preceptress request mourning
period to end on Mar. 81.

NEW YORK = Jackie Robinson,
Gov. Nelson Rockefeller new
Ambassador to Negro voters,
began his new duties last week
by taking verbal swings at Pres
ident Johnson 8 civil rights rec
ord.


The former Brooklyn Dodger
baseball star resigned as vice
president of the Chock Full
ONuts restaurant chain to serve
as one Of six deputy directors
Of the Governor 8 campaign staff.


His immediate task will be to
organize and supervise nation
wide network Of special campaign
committees. He will concentrate
on professional. sports, busi-
ness, consumer, and other
groups.


Robinson said he was "not con-
vinced that the fine speeches of
President Johnson provide suf-
ficient balance for the long rec
ord of opposition to meaningful
civil rights legislation."-


In 1860, Robinson, the first Ne
gro to play in organized baseball,
campaigned for Richard M. Nix
on.

jackie Robinson
to Aid RockefeIIer's
Political Program

William H. Sherrod, chief
grand mentor of the Grand Tenn
pies and Tabernacles of the


Knights and Daughters of Tabor,
International Order of Twelve,
California-Arizona Jurisdiction,
died Feb. 4, at San Francisco.


Funeral services we're held

The Blazers celebrated Valentine Day with dinner party
the Beefeaers Restaurant.


Seated Marlene Ovens Mrs bernard Oay'n
Jimmie Arlington, ardge and Mrs. Martyn Mooleton


Standing James Williams Elder Bernard LAYTON
Cavton Jerome Williams and Elder ]. P. Middleton.
